comment.author: 43688219@N00
comment._content: A Midshipman James William Bond was lost with the sinking of HMS Russell on the 27/04/1916. www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/3050634/BOND,%20JAMES... Russell was steaming off Malta early on the morning of 27 April 1916 when she struck two mines that had been laid by the German submarine U-73. A fire broke out in the after part of the ship and the order to abandon ship was passed; after an explosion near the after 12-inch (305-mm) turret, she took on a dangerous list. However, she sank slowly, allowing most of her crew to escape. A total of 27 officers and 98 ratings were lost. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Russell_(1901) There are records at the National Archive in the ADM 196/119/22 series for a Midshipman James William Bond, born 25th November 1896 who joined the Navy on the 15th September 1909. discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/SearchUI/Details?uri=D7... The 1911 census has a 14 year old James W, from Martham, Norfolk, who was recorded as a Naval Cadet at Osbourne Whippingham on the Isle of Wright. (James is not, however, remembered on the Martham War Memorial) Going back to the 1901 census the 4 year old James W was recorded at The Manor House, Cantley, Norfolk. This was the household of his parents, Henry K, (aged 44 and a Farmer from Ipswich) and Evelyn M, (aged 33 and from Hampshire). James has four brothers, plus there are 5 live in servants.
